text:
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

March 18
1953

Name: Oswald H. Hermle
Address: Marysburg, Sask.
Birthplace: Lincoln, Calif., U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1903
Where did you set up housekeeping? On Dad's Homestead
Where had you been living before that? Lincoln, California
For how many people did you prepare meals? They were six in our family
How far was it to your nearest store? 12 mi.
How often could a visit be made to the store? In second or third year 5 miles
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? The nearest store where everything could be had was Rosser, Sask., a good 50 miles away.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? I remember that we used XXXX flour and other brands.
One brand was Strong Baker 98 lb. or 49 lb.
In what quantities did you buy it? 25 lb. every 6 months
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 25¢
How much did you use graham flour? Very little
Whole wheat flour? We ground Wheat on Coffee Mill for Bread
Was flour milled locally? My Dad used to take Wheat to Aberdeen and later to Dunnville to trade for flour
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? None Whole Wheat? No other Farina?
Other? We used a huller barley for porridge in early years
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? First on Coffee Mill Later with Feed grinder

I was 7 years old at the time and of course with my parents, Theodore and Walburga Hermle. They homesteaded 9 mi. North West of Bents, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

March 18
1953

Name: Oswald H. Hermle
Address: Marysville, Sask.
Birthplace: Lincoln, Calif., U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1903

Where did you set up housekeeping? On Parks Highway and other places.

Where had you been living before that? In California.

For how many people did you prepare meals? They moved back on family.

How far was it to your nearest store? 1/2 mile away.

How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two weeks.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Groceries bought at local stores.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Armstrong's

In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lb. bags

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50

How much did you use graham flour? Very little

Whole wheat flour? Armstrong's

Was flour milled locally? No

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00

What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, flour, whole wheat, etc.

Other? None

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? With an old-fashioned hand mill.

I was 7 years old at the time and of course with my parents' Theodore and Wallace. They homesteaded 9 mi. North West of Buxton.
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...........................................
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...........................................
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...........................................
What size or tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...........................................
At what price? ..........................................................................................

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We bought a cow in Butten and took her along behind wagon to Homestead. A little later mother secured a brood hen and a setting of eggs.
That was the price of butter? ........................................... of eggs? ...........................................

Did you keep eggs for winter? ........................................... how? ...........................................

Did you make butter? ........................................... cheese? ...........................................
What kind of cheese? Mostly Cottage Cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Rabbit, wild chickens, some ducks. After we were established a few years ago occasionally.
How did you get fresh meat? Butchered a pig. Wild game was plentiful.
How often did you get fresh meat? That depended more or less on hunting luck.
How did you preserve meat? By curing with salt and smoking.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized? ...........................................
Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? As above.
For how long? I would say until about 1908 or longer.
What part did fish play in the family diet? We were not close to a lake with fish so they were only occasionally bought.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Frozen.
Kinds? .........................................................................................
3. **SUGAR AND SUGAR**

In what quantity did you buy 4 lbs. sugar?

That was the price for a ten pound sack of unrefined sugar?

At what price?

4. **Dairy Products**

Did you make butter? Yes

Did you purchase butter? No

Did you purchase cheese? Yes

5. **Meat and Fish**

For how long? For about 1908 or longer.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh

Kinds?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? .................. At what price? ..........
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ..................
Price? .................. That other beverages were used? Our beverages consisted mostly of coffee made from barley or wheat and milk.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? We got some.
If not, where from? We planted potatoes the first year.
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes .......... Cabbage .......... Carrots .......... Onions .......... Turnips .......... Beets
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? A few pounds at a time.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk.
What weight? About 5 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? By Box.
What was the price of prunes? ...........
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, peaches, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
The late was exceptionally good. We bought them in bags of about 25 lbs.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? .............
peas? .......... corn? .......... beans? .......... Saskatoons? .......... other foods? ..............................................................
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ....................
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ....................
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ....................
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ....................
To what extent? ........................................................................
Did you make your own vinegar? ................................................
Wild strawberries and raspberries were abundant in the earliest years because it rained more. There were also in most years lots of cherries and Saskatoons. All these berries provided cheap and delicious fruit.
6. **DEPENDING**
   - What kind of corn did you have? At what price?
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)
   - Price?

7. **COMMERCIAL QUANTITY OF COTTON**
   - From Bailey's Mill

8. **VEGETABLES**
   - Turnips
   - Potatoes
   - Carrots
   - Beets

9. **FRUITS**
   - Apples
   - Peaches
   - Grapes
   - Pears

10. **OTHER**
    - Beans
    - Corn
    - Other foods

11. **CONSERVATION**
    - Did you make your own preserves?
    - Wild strawberries and raspberries were abundant in the earliest years. Hemple also mentions it named more. They were also in great demand at Charles and Jackson Towns.

12. **ALL THAT HEMPLE PURCHASED CHEAP AND DELICIOUS FRUIT.**

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal East Cakes

Did you make yeast for your own use? Using starter?

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Baking soda?

Cream of tartar? Did you make your own baking powder?

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Point Cake
Did you make yeast for your own use? Using starter?
Using hops? Salt rising?
Did you buy baking powder? Baking soda?
Cream of tartar? Did you make your own baking powder?

N/A
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                                      | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon                             |                                        |                              | Since I cannot give details, asked here I will use this space for some other general remarks. |
| Canned sardines                           |                                        |                              | In the first years our grain often froze. The soil was so rich and moisture so abundant that the straw would get very tall and ripening was delayed. |
| Other canned fish that appeared early - give names |                                        |                              | We obtained the best samples of Wheat by cutting it on the green side and letting it ripen in the stock. If the stocks were capped the color of the wheat was much improved. |
| Apples - fresh                            |                                        |                              | Besides Oats we also grew an huller barley which almost looked like Wheat when threshed only longer kernels. From this we used for making Porridge and Coffee in the early years. This barley variety has disappeared and I did not see it anymore. I would say since about 1910 or 1912. |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) From shallow well besides Lake.

How far was this water from your home? ¼ mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Later on we dug a deeper well closer by the House.

The soil was no need and moisture so abundant that the straw would get very tall and dry. We obtained the first samples of wheat by cutting it when in the milk and leaving it upon in the stock. 12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ________ well, heater, Lake ________

How far was this water from your home? ________

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ________

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping; giving dates where possible.

I live am in a dugout well close by.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ________________________
If you made your own, did you use lye? ________________ wood ashes? ___________
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ________________________

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ________________________
Where did you get your fuel? ________________________
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We have used nothing but wood up to winter of 1952 when I bought an Oil space heater.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ________________________
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ________________________
By whom was your first cook stove made? ________________________
What year was it purchased? ________________________ Price? ________________________
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ________________________
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ________________________
When did you first see enamel ware? ________________________
Aluminum? ________________________

We bought China ware and I imagine cooking utensils along from California. Some of the China was broken because of careless repacking by Custom Officials.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Where did you get your fuel? Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

My house was built in 1952 when I bought an old Spanish Adobe.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? What year was it purchased? What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homeware) For preparing food? (chilis, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) When did you start using aluminum?

We bought China from California because some of the China was broken because of careless repacking by Custom Officials.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In 1903 - 1905 or 1908

Breakfast: Porridge, bread, butter, milk, Barry or Wheat Coffee.

Dinner: Wild meat, sometimes pork. Mother often made different kinds of noodles usually together with beans or prunes. Also jam cakes. We had potatoes, vegetables and bread. Beverage as for breakfast. Fruit at times.

Supper: Home made soup, fried potatoes. Bread, butter, drinks as above.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1903. The menu for this first Christmas I don't remember. But I strongly suspect it was not much different from every day. I remember for one of the first Christmases Dad brought a canned bone from Rosthern.

Those present were:

Dad age 48. Mother age 44. Myself age 7.

And my three sisters ages 5, 4, and 2 years.

The names of my sisters were: Cordula, Clara and Zita.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Thanks be to God, we always had enough to eat. It was not the modern fancy diet one sees almost everywhere in this district nowadays. But we were always healthy and despite many hardships never needed a doctor in the early years.

That refers to bought fruit. Whereas wild fruit was in season we had our fill. If I remember right there was a lack of sealers for canning in the first years. But later on Mother did a lot of preserving.
16. RECALL FOODS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the newspapers and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Jan. 1903 - 1905

Breakfast:
- Pancakes, bread, butter, milk, bread, milk, coffee.

Dinner:
- Milled meat, sometimes pork or chicken often.
- Mashed potatoes, often.
- Beans or peas.
- Bread, milk, coffee.

Supper:
- Home-made soup, fried potatoes, bread, milk.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1903. This meant for the first Christmas dinner in Western Canada.

I remember for one of the first Christmas dinner Dad brought a canned ham from Portland.

Three present were:

Dad age 48. Mother age 44. Myself age 7.

And my three sisters ages 5, 4, and 2 years.

The manner of any winter meal: Canned ham, beans and rice.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Thanks be to God, we always had enough to eat.

It was not the normal family diet and we almost everywhere in this district nowadays. But we were always healthy and despite many hardships never needed a doctor in all our years.

20. That refers to the family's health. When was the last time you were sick?

Notes on Western New York and New England. If you remember anything about the lack of medical facilities and the first doctors in the area.

A list of physicians.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Meals were prepared much more simple. Not so many different things on the table. Very seldom cake or pie.

(Continued from bottom) Mother used to relate during one of first winters. Feed for livestock was getting very low and my youngest sister prayed something like this: "Dear God let the snow melt. Our house needs hay and our cow needs grain." In fact, when Dad would cut grass with a scythe to put up feed for winter use.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We never relied solely on purchased foods even to this day. But as time went on and finances allowed, I would say from about 1910 and then on through the years we bought a limited quantity of prepared foods to provide a variety and change in our diet. Especially fruit as it became available was among the things we bought. I remember Dad used to buy apples by the barrel. That I think was in the years from 1908 to 1912 and later. The Grocer would always include a package of candy for our kids free of charge.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

From 1903 to 1906 everything had to be brought out from Rosthern by Wagon or Sleigh either by the settlers themselves or the store keepers. The Railway thru Humboldt, Brune, Dunn, had not been built yet.

Lugging everything the settlers needed 40 to 80 miles was no small chore.

In those years it really could rain. Wagons were often mixed in mud so that things had to be carried out by hand in order to get the wagons out. (See above)
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Meals were prepared much more simply. Not or many different things on the table. Very seldom.

Cake on first.

(Continued from letter) Mother used to select during our old first winter the feed for livestock was going very low and I helped myself to anything the kids liked. Dear God I did not want meat. Our house much hard and our own needs were great. In first year Dad worked out our own work a lot to keep my head for winter work.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We never relied solely on purchased foods even at this day. But as time went on and farming allowed, I would say from about 1910 and then on down the years we bought a limited quantity of prepared foods. To maintain a variety and change in our diet. Especially fruit as it became available was among the things we bought. Remember Dad used to buy apples by the barrel. That I think was in the fall from 1908 to 1912 and later. The store supplied almost entirely a feeding of Canning for kids free of charge.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing tools in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

From 1903 to 1906 everything had to be brought out from Portage by Wagon or sleigh either by the settlers them selves or the store keeper. The Railway thru Manitoba, Bunnell, Dunn, had not been built yet. Buying everything the settlers needed 40 to 80 miles was no small chore. Wagons in those years it really could rain. Wagons were often ruined in mud or snow. Hard to be carried out by hand in order to get the wagons out. (See above)
